articles.headline: Austin Orders U.S. Military to Step Up Efforts to Prevent Civilian Harm
articles.snippet: A new directive outlines steps intended to change how commanders think about their jobs, after New York Times investigations into botched airstrikes.
articles.abstract: A new directive outlines steps intended to change how commanders think about their jobs, after New York Times investigations into botched airstrikes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III ordered the military on Thursday to strengthen its efforts to prevent civilian deaths and to improve the way it investigates and acknowledges claims of civilian harm in U.S. combat operations.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Charlie Savage and Azmat Khan

articles.headline: India Schools Stay Closed, and Hopes Fade for a Lost Generation
articles.snippet: A large proportion of working-age people, once seen as a demographic advantage, could turn into a burden if many of them are undereducated and underemployed.
articles.abstract: A large proportion of working-age people, once seen as a demographic advantage, could turn into a burden if many of them are undereducated and underemployed.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Some children have forgotten the alphabet or what their classrooms look like. Others have dropped out of school entirely, scrounging for work and unlikely to ever resume their studies.
articles.byline: By Emily Schmall and Sameer Yasir

articles.headline: Growth Is Surging in Biden’s Economy. Why Don’t Voters Feel Better?
articles.snippet: President Biden is suffering in the polls as high inflation saps confidence in the economy, even as growth comes in strong.
articles.abstract: President Biden is suffering in the polls as high inflation saps confidence in the economy, even as growth comes in strong.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden is contending with an uncomfortable disconnect: The economy grew at the fastest pace since 1984 last year, but voters are downright pessimistic about economic conditions and their own financial prospects.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: Apple’s profit jumps to $34.6 billion in holiday quarter despite supply issues.
articles.snippet: The company’s revenue and profit beat Wall Street expectations, easing concerns that supply chain problems and the coronavirus were a drag on sales.
articles.abstract: The company’s revenue and profit beat Wall Street expectations, easing concerns that supply chain problems and the coronavirus were a drag on sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple weathered the supply chain snarls at the end of 2021 that tripped up the global electronics market and other industries, announcing on Thursday an 11 percent increase in revenue and a 20 percent jump in profit in its most recent quarter while offering optimism that the worst of the problems were behind it.

articles.headline: For Olympic Sponsors, ‘China Is an Exception’
articles.snippet: Pressure is mounting on companies to condemn the country’s human rights violations, but executives say the Games should not be politicized.
articles.abstract: Pressure is mounting on companies to condemn the country’s human rights violations, but executives say the Games should not be politicized.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the bottom of the slope where snowboarders will compete in the 2022 Beijing Olympics, an electronic sign cycles through ads for companies like Samsung and Audi. Coca-Cola’s cans are adorned with Olympic rings. Procter & Gamble has opened a beauty salon in the Olympic Village. Visa is the event’s official credit card.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Lori Lightfoot Promised to Change Chicago. Crises Keep Piling Up.
articles.snippet: Ms. Lightfoot has shown herself to be a blunt orator and unflinching negotiator.
articles.abstract: Ms. Lightfoot has shown herself to be a blunt orator and unflinching negotiator.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Days into a dispute between Mayor Lori Lightfoot and the Chicago Teachers Union, labor leaders outlined what they described as a grand compromise. Students, who had been receiving no instruction after teachers voted to stop reporting to classrooms amid a coronavirus surge, would attend a few days of online school, followed by a full, in-person return.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: France’s economy bounces back, while Germany’s falters under the strain of Omicron.
articles.snippet: The European Union’s two largest economies diverged in the final quarter of 2021.
articles.abstract: The European Union’s two largest economies diverged in the final quarter of 2021.
articles.lead_paragraph: France assumed Germany’s traditional role as the driving economic force in Europe after a strong finish to last year, while the German economy contracted in the final three months as it grappled with a resurgence of the coronavirus, official data showed Friday.

articles.headline: Stocks rally, erasing losses from a turbulent week.
articles.snippet: The S&P 500 rose 2.4 percent, its biggest one-day jump since June 2020. But some analysts cautioned against reading too much into a single day’s bounce.
articles.abstract: The S&P 500 rose 2.4 percent, its biggest one-day jump since June 2020. But some analysts cautioned against reading too much into a single day’s bounce.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street finally found a foothold on Friday, rebounding from days of back-to-back declines with its biggest gain in 18 months as investors grabbed on to glimmers of good news: a strong earnings report from Apple and data on wage growth that came in lower than expected.

articles.headline: Inflation Continued to Run Hot and Consumer Spending Fell in December
articles.snippet: Prices are rising rapidly, wages are growing and consumers are glum as a fraught economic moment poses big challenges for policymakers.
articles.abstract: Prices are rising rapidly, wages are growing and consumers are glum as a fraught economic moment poses big challenges for policymakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inflation came in strong and wage growth remained elevated at the end of 2021. At the same time, consumer spending fell in December as spiraling coronavirus caseloads kept many Americans at home and persistent supply chain bottlenecks disrupted holiday shopping.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: Pittsburgh Bridge Collapses Hours Before Biden Infrastructure Visit
articles.snippet: At least 10 people sustained non-life-threatening injuries, officials said. According to an analysis, addressing the structural issues of Pittsburgh’s nearly 450 bridges would cost $458 million.
articles.abstract: At least 10 people sustained non-life-threatening injuries, officials said. According to an analysis, addressing the structural issues of Pittsburgh’s nearly 450 bridges would cost $458 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — In the City of Bridges, it was not a standout. The bridge, four lanes of Forbes Avenue raised on a steel frame over a picturesque wooded ravine, carried traffic to and from the neighborhoods on the city’s East End. It was around 50 years old and, according to inspectors, in poor condition, but even by these measures was not particularly exceptional in Pittsburgh.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Sophie Kasakove
